fields.description:
h3. Background

# User exists in JIRA Internal Directory in lower-case (e.g.: {{captain.planet}}).
# User exists in Active Directory Connector in mixed-case (e.g.: {{Captain.Planet}}).
# User has membership to group ({{balsamiq-mockups-editors}}) in Active Directory only.
# Directory Order is:
## Internal Directory
## Active Directory

h3. Current Behaviour

User membership is calculated in all of the following areas. Screenshots are attached.

* GroupBrowser.jspa is displaying 3, when it should be 2.
* BulkEditUserGroups.jspa is displaying 2 correctly.
* UserBrowser.jspa, is displaying 3, including one that does not have group membership at all. It should only be displayed those two.

h3. Expected Behaviour

GroupBrowser.jspa and UserBrowser.jspa correctly calculate the number of users in the group as 2.

h3. Replication Steps

# Create user {{captain.planet}} in the JIRA Internal Directory.
# Add an Active Directory connector.
# Add user {{Captain.Planet}} from Active Directory.
# Add a new {{testgroup}} group.
# Change Active Director (AD) to be before JIRA Internal Directory (JID)
# Add the Active Directory user to that group.
# Change JID to be before AD.
# View the GroupBrowser, BulkEditUserGroups and UserBrowser to see the incorrect numbers.

(i) We do list duplicate usernames across directories as not being supported in [Managing Multiple Directories|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Managing+Multiple+Directories], however users cannot be easily deleted through the GUI without causing problems.
fields.summary: Mixed case usernames causes incorrect group membership calculation
Created vs Resolved Chart now missing vertical grid lines

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30077].
  {panel}

Would be good to have a "sum of" fields from time tracking field added to the 2 dimensional reports. In this way I could select my filter, select my X axis and then see how many total hours have been expended of a particular component.

For example if I had the following

Task 1 - UI - 2 Hours
Task 2 - UI - 6 Days
Task 3 - Services - 1 week
Task 4 - Database - 2 Hours
Task 5 - Database - 8 Hours
Task 6 - UI - 2 Hours

I am looking for an output that shows the following

Database - 1 Day 2 Hours
Services - 1 Week
UI - 6 Days 4 Hours


I want to aggregate hours across multiple issues, rather than manually having to tabulate them. I have components with the following names "UI","Services","Database". I then have issues which my developers log hours against. I then need to pull the total hours by component for a particular time period.

Nowadays the only possible way to achieve this is to create a filter and export it to Excel and generate the information from there.
fields.summary: New fields in 2 dimensional report gadget
Checkbox to send or not send email on bulk change page should be at the top
Rest API Documentation incorrectly lists "String" as a desired argument for "fields"
JQL key,issuekey searches should find moved issues
JQL Search when Link issue should have a paging option

Issue Statistics gadget is sorting issues based on status ids and not by names. This is confusing for the user. Next to this, it does not make much sense to sort by Status ids in the gadget.

Would be nice if we can change this.

Regards,
Ruchi

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30071].
  {panel}

The default date on Custom Field Date Time won’t show on the Edit screens and other screens, only on Create Issue screen 

To reproduce this:
# Create an Issue and name it Test1
# Create a custom field of _Date Time_ and name it TestDate1
# Assign TestDate1 in all the screens
# Configure the TestDate1 to have any other date
#* Click on _Edit Default Value_ and set the date to other date eg. 11/Sept/12
#* Leave the box untick and click _Set Default_ button
# Create an Issue and name it Test2, you will able to see the TestDate1 with the date inside (see newissue1.jpg)
# Open Test2 and edit the issue, you will able to see the date inside TestDate1 (see newissue2.jpg)
# Open Test1 and edit the issue, you will *not* able to see the date inside the TestDate1 (see oldissue1.jpg)

It would be nice if the existing issues (Test1) show the default date set for TestDate1 when editing issue and in other screens as well. Any other issue that has empty value for the TestDate1 could also automatically being set to the default date.
fields.summary: Custom field Date Time won’t show the default date on Screen

fields.description:
It's possible to have a custom field listed twice (the same custom field with the same id).

To reproduce you need to restart JIRA and create a custom field before custom fields cache was initialized (so you must not use View Custom Fields page before you create a custom field).

Found when running integration tests which create a custom field right after JIRA restore was run.
fields.summary: View Custom Fields shows the same custom field twice
Issue Collector does not work on Opera Browser

fields.description:
Attaching images to the issue causes a significant performance drop. For ~50 images, loading times jump to ~18 sec.

I've noticed this on Jira 5.0.7, 5.1 and 5.1.5 (and probably happens to the versions in between).

This seems to be caused by the usage of ZipFile from apache.compress rather than java.util (which was used in 5.0.5) in AttachmentZipKit. (see attached image)

Using the java.util version of ZipFile dropped the loading times for an issue with ~150 images from 47s to 12s.
fields.summary: Attachment thumbnails cause slow loading times in issue view
Upgrade Balsamiq to 2.1.19 or later

fields.description:
When adding multiple user to the role at the same time, JIRA will assume all the user as one single user(admin,test) which should be 2 users as admin and test respectively.

!project_people.jpg!

However, this works well in the Project Roles configuration("Administration" > "Users" > "Roles" > "Manage Default Members" of any role:

!roles.jpg!
fields.summary: Unable to add multiple user into Project Roles in a project at the same time

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30064].
  {panel}

When specifying an issue Original Estimate, we should be able to use decimal point for the estimate value, such as: 
- 1.3d or 3.3 

However, under certain time tracking configuration, inputting 2.3d value into Original Estimate will produce the following error:
- The original estimate specified is not valid
!2.png!

The steps to reproduce:
- Configure the Time Tracking, set the number of working hours per day to 7.5
!1.png!
- Try to create issue and specify 2.3d, and the problem is reproducible

Tested on JIRA 5.0, 5.1.x
fields.summary: Original Estimate do not accept 2.3d value

h3. Expected Behaviour

A sub-task is completed without error.

h3. Replication Steps

# Install 1.9.1.
# Create Vote Custom Field, Voters on an issue, Watchers on an issue and add them to appropriate screens.
# Attempt to create a sub-task.

h3. Workaround

Disable the plugin.
fields.summary: Creating a sub-task throws a NullPointerException and the issue cannot be created
Bring back the cross-application quick search bar in Atlassian OnDemand
Add some instance size logic to the JIRA OnDemand importer

fields.description:
When an user is removed from LDAP, they are not removed from the watcher list of an issue ticket.  This causes JIRA to hit a NPE and not send *any* notifications to any user.

This bug has become a bigger issue with the new AutoWatch function.

Tested on JIRA 5.1.6

Steps to reproduce:
* Have an issue ticket with working notifications
* Create new user in LDAP, with a valid e-mail address
* Within JIRA, setup a new directory, connecting to LDAP
* Synchronise your LDAP directory
* Login as the new user from LDAP
* Watch an issue ticket
* Remove this user from LDAP
* Perform another Sync, removing this user from JIRA
* Perform an issue action on the 'watched' ticket
* Observe that no notifications are sent (mail queue remains empty)
* Logs show:
{code}

(!) *Backup your database first*
{code:sql}
select * from userassociation where source_name = 'testuser' and association_type = 'WatchIssue';
{code}
fields.summary: Mail notification fails when LDAP user is removed but still listed as watcher
Typo in jql linkedIssues error message

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30056].
  {panel}

When doing a global quick search, include labels in fields to search.

Steps to reproduce
1. Create an issue
2. Add a label to it such as "ACMEInc"
3. Enter "ACMEInc" in quick search and press Enter

Expected results
Issues that include the label (tag) "ACMEInc" show up in search result

Actual results
Issues that include the label "ACMEInc" do not show up in search results 

I'm basing this off the idea that Labels are the same or similar to "tags" or "keywords".
fields.summary: Include labels field as search criteria in the global search box by default
Issue update emails are garbled for particular issues
Moving issues to new project should move versions and components

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30053].
  {panel}

Currently, there is a guide on this at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/ATLAS/JIRA+Performance+Testing+with+Grinder

However, this guide is very general and thus insufficient. Add more detail steps so that new users should be able to understand it easily.

A few things that we can improve is:
* should have separate steps to run the test with maven and without maven.
* specify which grinder.properties that need to be modified based on the method used
* in the Grinder.properties file I think we should mention that the exact location of the files need to be specify. (i) example is good
* suggest a clear directory where the jira_users.txt, jira_projects.txt and jira_issues.txt should be created (this is related to point 2)
* suggest in which particular directory user should run the mvn command
* explicitly specify which log can be analyse using the available third party tools (eg: The Grinder Analyzer)
* after converting the log to CSV, provide example on how to utilise the data to generate chart.
fields.summary: Improve the guide on JIRA Performance Test Using Grinder

fields.description:
The JIRA REST API makes it easy to harvest email addresses as an anonymous user.
1. Go to https://jira.atlassian.com/browseJRA-22053 as anonymous. Note that you can't extract email addresses from this page unless the user has used an email address as her username.
2. Now go to https://jira.atlassian.com/rest/api/2/issue/JRA-22053?expand=changelog, still as anonymous. The response contains the reporter email, as well as an email address for every history item. (!)

Whenever we return email addresses in the REST API we should use a  [com.atlassian.jira.util.EmailFormatter|http://docs.atlassian.com/jira/latest/com/atlassian/jira/util/EmailFormatter.html] to make sure that they are masked as per the email display configuration.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30031].
  {panel}

Inside the Application access of an OnDemand instance we can set how many users are active, thus counting towards to the customer license. However, when creating an user, inside the *Users* screen (clicking on the *'+ Create User'* button, beside the *'Invite Users'*) we can see a message which says:

{quote}
There are currently *X* total user(s) set up in JIRA, of which *Y* are active and count towards your license limit.
{quote}

*However*, this *Y* number ignores if an user has or not *application access* to JIRA. This Y is measured by the condition of the user being part of a group.

Example:

I have a *50* users limit license and *45* users set up in JIRA.

!create_new_user.png!

The message says that: of which *45* are active and count towards your license limit.

However, if a go to my application access, only *41* users has access to JIRA and are *actually* counting towards to the license (41 users active, 3 users inactive and 1 user sysadmin).

!application_access.png!

Which gives me *9 remaining* users. However, when looking at the first screen, it confuses the real number of users which are actually active and counting towards the license.

---

We have two screens showing the same information with different results, how many users are active and counting towards the license. This conflicting information is impacting the user management when they are running out of licenses available.
fields.summary: Active number of users on 'Create User' message mismatch Application Access

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When Creating a new issue, a button is presented that allows users to 'Configure Fields', which allows the user to show a customised sub-set of the fields that have been configured for the Create issue Screen. This functionality is further described in: [Creating an Issue|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Creating+an+Issue]

The expectation is that Required Fields are *never* hidden from the user. Some circumstances allow for Users to hide required custom fields. 

This functionality of hiding fields can not be easily disabled as per: [JRA-27707|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-27707]

Most Fields appear to function in an expected manner. 


h3. Environment
- This behaviour was observed on a new JIRA 6.4.9 instance without any custom Add-ons installed.
- The Browser used to access the JIRA instance was: Google Chrome: 44.0.2403.130.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a custom field (Checkbox type is a good example) and add it to the Create Issue Screen.
# Create a new project using the modal style create an issue. 
# Observe that the user is able to customise the Fields being shown. It is possible to hide a required field (checkbox type)
!checkbox02.png|thumbnail!
# When the user attempts to submit the form, if the required field does not have a value, it is shown when the hidden field fails to validate.
!checkbox03.png|thumbnail!
h3. Expected Results
If a field is required, it should not be possible for a user to hide the filed.

h3. Actual Results
It is currently possible to hide required fields as per the screenshot below.

h3. Notes
# The field is shown if it does not have a value on attempting to create the issue.
# The Fields can not be configured if the user is not using the Create issue Dialog box.
# In my testing, using JIRA 6.4.9: I was unable to observe this behaviour with the following field types:
#- Select
#- Text Area
#- Label
#- Date
#- Date Time
#- Number
#- Multi-line text area.
# In my testing, using JIRA 6.4.9: Was able to observe this issue with:
#- Checkbox
fields.summary: Configure Fields button allows users to hide Required Checkbox Fields

  {panel}

This might be related to implementation of JRA-27396.

I have an issue that I want to assign. After I click "Assign" button, the popup appears and some user's name is already selected in Assignee field. If I press the down arrow in that field, I see this:

*Suggestions*
Unassigned
Automatic
John Doe
Stuart Smith
Wendy Wang
----------------------
_Start typing for users_
*All Users*
Abe Lincoln
John Kennedy
William McKinley

The *All Users* list is much longer in our case (about 160). Users who are in the suggested list (John Doe, Stuart Smith, Wendy Wang) are missing from *All Users* list.

This is counterproductive as some JIRA users like me never use the suggested list and scroll straight to all users list, but are unable to find the user they are looking for. Please make *All Users* really an all-user list.
fields.summary: Suggested users to be assigned are not in "All Users" list

  {panel}

We already have the feature to change the Owner of Shared Filters and Dashboards.

However, in changing the owner of the shared filter, one have to go to the owner page > Manage filter > My filter in order to edit the following filter.  If the user has more than 200 filters to manage, this would be a trouble to them.  Another way is to use the Issue Navigator for searching of purpose, which still could be a hassle for some.

A customer requested to have an Improvement to already an awesome feature.  To be able to click on the Shared Filter name (as image below) and be directed to the filter in the Issue Navigator, from there the user could then continue to modify the filter and such.  This would really improve the productivity of the user in managing the shared filters.

This improvement request might also applicable to the Shared Dashboards as well.
fields.summary: Make filter clickable in Shared Filter administration

Our Jira is connected to the external LDAP directory via Crowd. We have no control over LDAP directory contents and from time to time users are removed from the directory (~1 year after they left).

fields.description:
A user's username is injected into the "rel" attribute of the user mention link without being encoded properly. This means that if the username contains a " character then new attributes can be injected into the <a> user mention link element. Hence, providing a persistent xss vector.

To reproduce this issue:
1. add or sign up as a user called: " onmouseover="alert(3)" 
2. mention the user in an issue: [~" onmouseover="alert(3)"]
3. refresh the page
4. hover over the user's mention link
5. observe an alert prompt containing the value of 3 within it.
fields.summary: persistent xss in a user's username within mentions within comments

  {panel}

Local directory migration replaces password hash with 'nopass' 

Creating a user directory for migration from internal replaces the password hash in the CREDENTIAL field in cwd_user with 'nopass'.

If you need to revert from LDAP to internal by moving those users back, all passwords must be reset.

To put it mildly, this is a *major* pain.
fields.summary: Support migration from LDAP back to internal user directory

h3. Summary
When using Print Preview mode in browsers like Firefox, IE and Google Chrome, if the scale chosen is 100%, then the user would be unable to view the entire page. Parts of it wouldn't be shown.

An example :

!Print Preview in Firefox.jpg|thumbnail! 

h3. Steps to reproduce

# Access a JIRA instance using either Firefox or IE
# Access the 'Print Preview' option of the browser
# Set the scale to 100% (actually it also manifests if the scale is 90% or 80%)

h3. Additional Notes

* Printing the document will show the attachment printed incorrectly

h3. Workaround

* The whole document can be viewed in 100% scale if the orientation is set from 'Portrait' to 'Landscape'
* To print the attachment, download the file and print it with native application.
fields.summary: Unable to view full page in Print Preview mode

fields.description:
From JiraWebActionSupport.java:
{code}
    public String getUserFullName(String username)
    {
        User user = getUserManager().getUser(username);
        if (username == null)
        {
            log.warn("Could not retrieve full name for user '" + username + "'! User does not exist!");
            return username;
        }
        return user.getDisplayName();
    }
{code}

It seems pretty clear that the intended test is "if (*user* == null)".  There could be some really nasty problems that this causes elsewhere, but so far all I have seen is a scary-but-innocuous stack trace in the logs from doing this:

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29982].
  {panel}

Fill in the required details in the Create JIRA Issue tab.

Then, either press the Enter key several times quickly, or click the 'Create' button repeatedly.
Many duplicate issues will be created.

It will be great if the dialog prevent you from submitting the request after the first time.
fields.summary: If continuously press Enter key, multiple of issues get created

fields.description:
As a context of the test instance, we've got : 
* 335243 issues.
* 6963 project versions.
* 3347 released versions.
* 3613 no release versions.

when running the issue search with these two different JQL query: 
# Search issue include the release version, which should return 46 issue.
{code}
project = "test" AND (fixVersion in releasedVersions())
{code}
# Search issue not include the release version, which should return 35 issues.
{code} 
project = "test" AND (fixVersion NOT in releasedVersions())
{code}

The result is that the first one return the search output very fast, but not the second one which is taking 3 or 4 times longer then the first one.
fields.summary: The "NOT IN" statement causes a performance issue for the release version search

fields.description:
Following workflow steps:
Assign / Start Progress / Resolve / Reopen / Start Progress / Stop Progress
The status is changed to "Open" but then receive error:
"Error marking step #183175 finished: root cause: Tried to update an entity that does not exist".  
(the issue appears to be correctly updated and workflow can proceed)
This happens consistently with the steps above, but does not occur for:
Assign / Start Progress / Stop Progress

I see that someone else has the same issue but no answer to date:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/80886/errors-on-stopping-progress
fields.summary: Workflow error when "Stop Progress" - Tried to update an entity that does not exist

fields.description:
When using the Workload Chart tallying statistics by Label, the plugin counts each issue once for each label, which causes duplication for issues with more than one label.

To reproduce:

# Create a Project
# Create one issue in this Project
# Install Plugin
# Enter time tracking into the issue
# Add two labels to the issue
# Apply Workload Chart to Dashboard
# Configure gadget to show your new Project by Label
fields.summary: When using the Workload Chart, tickets can be counted twice.

fields.description:
In JIRA 4.x, when a user edited an issue's labels, they got to select whether notifications were sent for that change.  This feature seems to have disappeared in 5.x with the introduction of inline editing for other issue fields.

We go through and add labels to lots of issue to help organize things, and it's kind of annoying that each edit now triggers a separate notification.
fields.summary: No longer any way to suppress notifications for Label edits
Add other Atlassian Apps to the JIRA Menu

fields.description:

This makes no sense. The Universal Package Manager doesn't directly affect the stuff that is indexed, like issues.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29961].
  {panel}

This is an important accessibility feature. It is something common for people to copy and paste data to forms and when they are doing this they may add a leading or trailing space by mistake to these fields.

With current implementation this space is preserved and causing problems in numerous situations.

So far, I do no see any use case for not implementing this, even for *all* input forms.

Here are some places where this would be very helpful (:
* Filter Users: User Name Contains, Full Name Contains, Email Contains
* Add Custom Field and Add Custom Field Values.

Note: for "email contains" it would be great to auto-strip non email parts: like "John Doe <john.doe@acme.com>" to become "john.doe@acme.com", or "mailto:john@xx.com" -> ""john@xx.com". It is common to get these formats when you copy/paste and email from different places.
fields.summary: Auto stripping of leading and trailing white spaces from all Jira text input form controls

fields.description: We are calling JIRA each minut to synchronize bugs in it. But the sessions in JIRA remain opened. As I have talked to support, it is not a major issue, because after 300 minutes they are closed on time-out. But if we will use the webservice interface more extensively, it will caused problems on server memory.
fields.summary: Not closing web service sessions in JIRA

fields.description:
*Steps to replicate*
# Navigate to the Plugins page and click on the *Show System Plugins* link
# Locate the *Web Resources Plugin* and show the modules (110 modules by default)
!1.JPG!
# Locate the *avatar-picker* module and disable it
!2.JPG!
# Go back to the *Dashboard* and nothing is shown. The drop-down menu are not clickable
!3.JPG!
# Even going back to the *Plugins* page, nothing is rendered and UPM is not showing
!4.JPG!

*Workaround*
# Using *Google Chrome*, download the *REST Console* extension
# Fill up the necessary information to fire the request again
!fix_1.JPG!
(i) Replace the *localhost:8514/jira* with the URL of your instance
!fix_2.JPG!
!fix_3.JPG!
!fix_4.JPG!
(i) Make sure you click on *Basic Auth* and fill up the username and password
!fix_5.JPG!
# The *avatar-picker* module should be re-enabled again
fields.summary: Disabling the "avatar-picker" module from the "Web Resources" System Plugin breaks JIRA and UPM
